Award.AwardTitle: Becoming the Online Resource Center for Ethics Education in Engineering and Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will fund the creation of an Online Ethics Center for Engineering and Science (OEC) which will be an expansion of the existing National Academy of Engineering?s (NAE) Online Ethics Center for Engineering and Research (OEC) to include resources for all the fields that NSF supports. Collaboration with the Ethics Education Library (EEL) of the Center for the Study of Ethics in the Professions (CSEP) at the Illinois Institute of Technology (IIT) will provide access to a wider array of materials than will be housed in the OEC and promote interactions with other repositories of ethics-related information. The OEC will develop best practices in ethics training, foster research on ethical issues in science, mathematics, and engineering in both national and international contexts, and serve as a living resource of multimedia materials that may be used to train current and future generations of scientists, mathematicians, and engineers in ethics and responsible conduct of research.


The Online Ethics Center will help educators, researchers, administrators, undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and practicing scientists and engineers understand the scope of existing knowledge about both ethics and ethics education in science, mathematics, and engineering. One of the intents of this resource center is to help scholars and institutions meet NSF's implementation of Section 7009 of the America Creating Opportunities to Meaningfully Promote Excellence in Technology, Education, and Science (America COMPETES) Act by providing easy access to high quality case studies, best practices, and original scholarship in ethics in all of the fields that NSF supports.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the Becoming the Online Resource Center for Ethics Education in Engineering and Science project was to expand the National Academy of Engineering?s (NAE) Online Ethics Center for Engineering and Science (OEC) to become the go-to online source for resources and assistance for ethics education in both science and engineering. The project significantly enhanced the OEC?s content, capabilities, and user base by

(1)   Improving accessibility, use, and interactivity for all science and engineering fields

(2)   Emphasizing issues in responsible research, social responsibility, and social justice

(3)   Incorporating resources from international contributors and about global topics in science and engineering

(4)   Promoting cooperation and deliberation among users.

Technical upgrades to the site improved access to the OEC resource collection, which was migrated from static web pages to a fully searchable database-driven site. This transformation included newly indexing materials by 49 topic areas in the two major categories of Ethics and Society, and Research and Practice. A homepage redesign improved readability and clarity. ?Field? pages highlight discipline-specific new and recommended teaching materials, events, and other resources. A new ?Teaching Ethics? page assists faculty in integrating ethics in courses.

The project also expanded the team supporting the site. An advisory board provides high-level guidance on collection priorities, and editorial board members solicit and review submissions. The peer review process creates value for both collection users and contributors by ensuring resource quality. A new online form for submitting resources and clear resource review criteria enable the editorial board to handle submissions efficiently.

A site community was established with the creation of individual ?Profile Pages? and a newsletter. The Profile Pages allow community members to post a short biography and link to OEC resources that they authored, and to post announcements in a community feed. A quarterly newsletter highlights current issues in S&E ethics and new resources on the site.

The expanded OEC collection features over 350 new resources. For example, subject aids?minibibliographies for beginners?were developed to help site visitors new to STEM ethics. They provide a brief overview of a topic; references to selected high-quality topic introductions in journal articles, book chapters, videos, or other materials available publicly or through academic libraries; access to major international or US policies, codes, and other guidance material; and links to more extensive topic bibliographies. Subject aids can be accessed through the main resource search (the onlineethics.org glossary) and pages of others, such as cases. The site now provides searchable access to over 80 Academy reports with substantial ethics content, a rich source of literature reviews that can be used in teaching either by directly assigning them to students or mining them for further materials. New Project Pages include submissions detailing the work of a variety of ethics education programs.

The Ethics Education Library (EEL) at the Illinois Institute of Technology Center for the Study of Ethics in the Professions (CSEP), an OEC co-PI and partner site, has made major contributions to OEC and EEL resources, including 28 new and 21 updated bibliographies on the OEC and over 12,500 new references added to the EEL. The EEL database of STEM ethics scholarly literature complements the OEC collection of STEM ethics education resources.

Arizona State University (ASU), an OEC co-PI, has focused on expanding resources on ethics in the life and environmental sciences, contributing new resource collections of cases with commentaries, a class plan, a syllabus, and a bibliography in the areas of Emerging Biotechnologies, Human Enhancement, Conservation and Biodiversity, and Big Data in the Life Sciences. To build community awareness of the OEC and its new resources the ASU team presented them at professional conferences of the American Society of Engineering Ethics, Association for Practical and Professional, Society for Ethics Across the Curriculum, and North American Congress for Conservation Biology.

The ASU team also cohosted a workshop aimed at building capacity for teaching STEM ethics and adding to the OEC collection. The Research Ethics & Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR) Special Interest Section (SIS), Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) SIS, and the Online Ethics Center?s Life and Environmental Sciences Section convened the APPE 2018 preconference workshop on ?Teaching Research Ethics and Scientific Integrity.? The workshop provided a forum for both novice and experienced ethics instructors to hone their skills by presenting STEM ethics education resources to peers and receiving feedback, learn about OEC new and updated online resources, and submit workshopped resources to the OEC for posting.

At the University of Delaware, an OEC project partner, the International Perspectives group identified information resources on international organizations and projects. The team revised and developed international case studies for pedagogical use in the topical fields of the OEC, identified OEC resources of international interest to facilitate access to them, and worked with partners in Spain and Guatemala on pedagogical projects for Spanish-speaking students and scholars.
